sp.p: No, no, Bobby, in The Reclaim'd Rake, and The Conſtant Lovers, and Sir Charles Grandiſon, and Roderic Random, and—

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; they live at Random, with Sir Charles Grandiſon.—Now d'ye know 'em?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! you are a charming little Lawyer, (to Sophy) and might, perhaps, eſtabliſh your proofs for precedents, if Sir Charles Grandiſon was on the Bench: yet I never heard of his being made Chief-Juſtice, tho' I never thought him fit for any thing elſe.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: What the Devil's this?—What, did not you bring all thoſe fine proofs from faſhionable life?—And are you ſuch a fool as not to underſtand what we call common-place?

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: Common-place!

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Yes, we perſons of elegant life uſe the figure Hyperbōle.—

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: Hyperbōle! What's that?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Why, that's as much as to ſay, a ſtretch.

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: A ſtretch! What, then, you have been mocking me, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt; I ſhall be the happieſt man exiſting to, to— (aſide) Egad, I muſt take care of my phraſes!—I mean, that I ſhall be always, and upon all occaſions, your moſt devoted, tres humblement ſerviteur.—Were there ever two ſuch Bumpkins!

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: What's he gone? Oh! Villain! Monſter! I am forſaken! Oh! I am rejected!—All Cornwall will know it!

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Tin-Mines and all. But don't ye cry, Miſs Pendragon—don't ye cry!

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: Oh! I am rejected!

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p:
I am glad on't, with all my heart! I'll challenge him yet, and they won't know in Cornwall exactly how it was.—They'll hear that a Lord fought about ye, and all
that ſort of thing; and whether for ye or againſt ye, 'twill be much the ſame.

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: But will you challenge him, really, Bobby?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Upon honor!—I admire the claw of the thing! Egad, Sophy, I'm glad he's forſaken thee! Now my character will be finiſh'd. A man can't ſhew his face in company, till he has ſtood ſhot, and fired his piſtol in the air.

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: In the air! If you don't fire it thro' him—

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Oh, never fear! I'll do all that ſort of thing. Come along! I'll go home directly, and practiſe at the hen-coop in the yard. I'll fire thro' one end, and you ſhall hold your calaſh againſt the other; and if I don't hit it, ſay I'm no markſman.

div.stage: [Exit Pendragon, with Sophy under his arm.

div.head: SCENE III.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: I intreat your pardon for conducting you to my own lodgings;—but here, Madam, you will be ſafe, 'till you determine how to act.—What are your commands for me?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Beauchamp, I have no commands—I have no deſigns!—I have been very imprudent; I am ſtill more unhappy.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Shall I acquaint Mr. Fitzherbert?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: It was to avoid him that I left Lady Bell.—I have reaſons that make it impoſſible to ſee Mr. Fitzherbert now.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Is there no other friend?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: O yes, I have one friend!—Were he here, all my difficulties would vaniſh!—It may ſeem ſtrange, Mr. Beauchamp, but I expect that you believe—Heavens! here's company! (looking at the wing) 'Tis Miſs Belmour—the laſt woman on earth whom I would truſt!—Where can I go?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Miſs Belmour! Very odd!—But pray be not uneaſy!—That room, Madam, if you will condeſcend—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! ha! I expect your gravity to be amazingly diſcompos'd at ſo hardy a viſit; but I took it very ill that you did not deſign to call upon me before your departure;
and ſo as I was paſſing your door, I ſtopp'd in mere frolic to enquire the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Beauch
sp.p: You do me infinite honour, Madam! I am thankful that I fail'd in my attention, ſince it has procur'd me ſo diſtinguiſh'd a favour.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh, your moſt obedient!—You are going to leave England for a long while! You'll find us all in different ſituations, probably, on your return!—Your friend Lord Sparkle, for inſtance—I am inform'd that he is really to marry Lady Bell Bloomer; but I don't believe it—do you?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible, Madam, for me—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Poh! poh! impoſſible! Such friends as you are I ſuppoſe keep nothing from one another.—We women can't exiſt without a confidante; and I dare ſay, you men are full as communicative. Not that it is any thing to me; but as I have a prodigious regard for Lady Bell—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Heaven and earth, how unlucky! Here's ſome man! I am the niceſt creature breathing in my reputation: what will he think? I'll run into this room.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam, you cannot enter there!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I muſt—Oh—oh! the door is held, Sir.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: My dear Madam, I am infinitely ſorry for the accident; but ſuppoſe—ſuppoſe, I ſay, Ma'am, that a friend of mine has been in a duel, and conceal'd in that room.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ridiculous! I ſaw the corner of a hoop and a white ſattin petticoat:—is that the dreſs of your duelling friends? I will go in.— (ſtruggling) So! (flinging away ſpitefully) 'tis too late!
So! ſo! ſo! I beg your pardon. How could you be ſo indiſcreet, Beauchamp? Tho' a young ſoldier, I thought you knew enough of Generalſhip to be prepar'd for a ſurprize.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh, ſo he was; but not for two ſurprizes.—One has happened already, and a haſty retreat the conſequence.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Believe me, Belville—I am infinitely concerned

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh! I deteſt your impertinent concern! Keep it for the Lady in the other room.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: A Lady in the other room too! Heydey! Beauchamp, who would have ſuſpected—

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: 'Tis all a miſtake! The Lady in the next room—But prithee go.—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Only tell me if you have ſeen Fitzherbert. I have been ſeeking him this hour, on a buſineſs of the utmoſt conſequence.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: I have not; but about this time you'll find him at home.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Enough! Miſs Belmour, pray ſuffer no concern; depend on my honour.—Beauchamp (taking him aſide), who is the Lady in the other room?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Had I meant you to have known, that room would have been unneceſſary.

div.stage: (Belville ſeems ſtill inquiſitive; Beauchamp draws him towards the wing).

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Now do I die to know who it can be! Indeed, 'tis neceſſary for my own ſake.—Whilſt ſhe has been hid, I have been expoſed; and who knows what the creature may ſay? I'll try once more. She has my ſecret, and I'll have her's.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Belville!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Miſs Manners!—Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, Belville, throw me not from you!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhing!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh charming! The modeſt Julia, and the reſerv'd Beauchamp! Ha! ha! ha!—But Mr. Belville, how came you of this ſober party? ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Speak to me!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Now, Mr. Beauchamp, you know the purport of my viſit.—I had heard that Miſs Manners has been ſeen to viſit you, and, not being willing to truſt to ſuch a report, was reſolved, if poſſible, to diſcover the truth.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Wretched woman!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Barbarous creature! Oh hear me, I conjure you!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
Hear you!—No, madam;—and if my contempt, my hatred, my—oh!—You, Sir, I muſt ſpeak to in another place;—yet perhaps you were not acquainted that—What would I ſay!—The word which I have pronounced
with rapture, choaks me. From this moment farewel!

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: What can I think of all this?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh Sir!

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Permit me, Madam, to aſk i you have long known Mr. Belville?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yes, too long.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh, oh, too long!—Aye, young ladies ſhould be cautious how they form acquaintance. For my part—But you look ill, child!— (taking her by the hand) Well, I have no hard heart; I can pity your weakneſs, Miſs;—I won't upbraid you now.—My coach waits;—ſhall I conduct you home?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yes, to Lady Bell—to Lady Bell—I am very ill!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Adieu, Mr. Beauchamp! This has been an unlucky frolic!—'Tis amazing, you grave people can be ſo careleſs.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: An unlucky frolick, indeed! And I am ſo thoroughly confounded, that I know not what judgment to form of the adventure.—I always conſidered Miſs Manners as a pattern of delicacy and virtue; nor dare I now, ſpite of circumſtances, think otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: So, ſo, Signor Quixote! What ſo ſoon loſt your prize! Aye, you ſee quarrelling for theſe virtuous women, is as unprofitable as the aſſault of the windmills.—Have you ſeen Lady Bell in my behalf?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Lady Bell, my Lord! Why, ſure, 'tis impoſſible after your attempt on Miſs Manners—

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Pſha! that is a ſtroke in my favour. Women like to receive the devoirs of thoſe, whom others of their ſex have found ſo dangerous. What did you diſcover of Lady Bell's ſentiment towards me?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: I meant to have given the intelligence ſoftened, but the agitations of my mind make it impracticable; I muſt, therefore, inform you in one word, Lady Bell Bloomer's choice is made, and that choice has not fallen upon your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p:
Then I muſt inform you in two words, that I
am convinced you are miſtaken. But your reaſons, Sir, your reaſons?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Her Ladyſhip furniſhed me with a deciſive one: ſhe acknowledged a pre-engagement; and added, if I viſited her this evening, I ſhould ſee her in the preſence of the man her heart prefers.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Excellent! charming ingenuity! Ha! ha! ha! the kindeſt, ſofteſt, meſſage that ever woman fram'd; and you, like the ſheep loaden with the golden fleece, bore it inſenſible of its value.—Ha! ha! ha! you can't ſee through the pretty artifice?

sp.speaker: Bauch.
sp.p: No, really.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Why, 'tis I who am to be there; there by particular invitation. You'll ſee her in my preſence; and this was her pretty myſterious way of informing me that I am the object of her choice.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Without a doubt! But you deep people are the dulleſt fellows at a hint; a man of half your parts would have ſeen it.—But I am ſatisfied, and ſhall go to her route in brilliant ſpirits.—You ſhall come, and ſee my triumph confirmed.—Come, you rogue! and ſee the lovely Widow in the preſence of the man her heart prefers.—Poor George! You muſt have been curſedly ſtupid, not to have conceiv'd that I was the perſon.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Yes, I will come.—Oh vanity! I had dared to explain—Yes, I conſtrued the ſweet confuſion—Oh, I bluſh at my own arrogance! Lord Sparkle muſt be right.—Well, this night decides it.—Narrowly will I watch each tone and look, to diſcover—Oh!—ever-bleſt!—he whom her heart prefers!

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: An Apartment at LADY BELL's. A Table, with Candles.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: ARE the tables placed in the outer room?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Ma'am, all but the Pharaoh-table.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Then carry that there too.—I poſitively will not have a table in the drawing-room.— [Exit Servant. Thoſe who play don't viſit me, but the card-tables; and where they find them is very immaterial.—Let me ſee! For whiſt, Sir James Jennet—Lady Ponto—Mrs. Lurchem, and Lady Carmine.—For Pharaoh, Mrs. Evergreen, Lord Dangle, Sir Harry—Hey-dey!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Come, child, don't faint!—You had more cauſe for terror half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Heavens, Julia! where have you been?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ay, that's a circumſtance you would not have known, but for an accident; and I am very ſorry it fell to my lot to make the dicovery.

sp.speaker: Lady Bell.
sp.p: Speak, my love!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Miſs Belmour will tell you all ſhe knows.—I am too wretched!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Nay, as to what I know,—I know very little.—I can tell what I ſaw, indeed.—Having received intimations not quite conſonant to one's notions of decorum, I pretended a frolick, and called on Mr. Beauchamp, and there I found this Lady concealed.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Heavens, Julia! 'Tis impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Nay, ſhe can't attempt to deny what I myſelf ſaw.—Other diſcoveries had liked to have been made too; but Miſs Manners may explain them herſelf; for I ſee your rooms begin to fill.—I ſhall report that your Ladyſhip is a little indiſpoſed, as an excuſe for your not immediately appearing.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Julia! You at Mr. Beauchamp's!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Lady Bell, tho' I have acted raſhly, and was indeed found there, I am not the guilty creature you imagine.—I am married!—I will no longer conceal it!

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Married! Oh Heavens!
sp.stage: (throws herſelf in a chair, with her back to Julia)

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I dared not reveal it to my guardian, and for that reaſon fled from your houſe.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: O Julia, and you are married! What a ſerpent have I nouriſhed!—But forgive me!—You knew not—alas! I knew not myſelf, till this moment, how much—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: My deareſt Madam, do not add to my afflictions!—for indeed they are ſevere.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Ungenerous Girl! why did you conceal from me your ſituation?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Good Heavens! is it deſtin'd that one imprudent ſtep is to loſe me every bleſſing! In the agonies of my heart I flew to your friendſhip, and you kill me with reproaches.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: And you have killed me by your want of confidence! Oh, Julia! had you revealed to me—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I dared not; for when Mr. Belville prevailed on me to give him my hand—

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Mr. Belville!—Mr. Belville, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yes; it was in Paris we were married.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: So, ſo, ſo; what a pretty miſtake I made!—But it was a miſtake! . . . . . . . . . . And ſo my ſweet Julia is married! married in Paris! Sly thing! But how came you at Mr. Beauchamp's, my Love?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: In my raſh flight this morning, my wicked Maid betray'd me into Lord Sparkle's houſe.—There Mr. Beau—champ ſnatch'd me from ruin, and gave me a momentary aſylum in his lodgings.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Did Beauchamp!—But what is his worth and his gallantry to me? Can't he do a right thing, but my heart muſt triumph?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: At Mr. Beauchamp's my huſband found me;—and found me hid with ſo ſuſpicious a ſecrecy!—Hah! Here comes Mr. Fitzherbert! How can I ſee him?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: My Julia!—My dear Julia!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh Sir!—

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Come, I know all; and to relieve one cauſe of your diſtreſs, will tell you that the lover I ſhock'd you with today, was only my agent in the little revenge I had reſolv'd to take for your having married, without my conſent, the very man for whom all my cares deſign'd you.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: —Is it poſſible!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: At the moment he left Paris for Florence, you received my directions to return home: thus Belville's letters miſs'd you, and he remain'd ignorant that you were in London.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh Sir! had you reveal'd this to me this morning, what evils ſhould I have eſcap'd?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: My dear girl, I decreed you a little puniſhment; but your own raſhneſs has occaſioned you a ſeverer portion than you deſerv'd.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: But where is the Bridegroom? I long to ſee the necromancer, whoſe ſpells can thaw the Veſtal's heart, and light up flames in the cold region of a monaſtery.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: He is without, ſatisfied from the mouth of Beauchamp of your conduct, (to Julia) and impatient to fold his Julia to his heart.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh Sir, lead me to him!—To find my huſband, and to be forgiven by you, are felicities too great.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: What a diſcovery has Julia's marriage made to me of my own heart! I have perſuaded myſelf it knew no paſſion but the deſire of conqueſt; that it knew no motive to admiration but vanity; but the pangs of jealouſy prov'd to me, in one moment, that all its ſenſe is love!

div.stage: An elegant Apartment lighted up, Card-parties ſeen.—Two Servants carrying Refreſhments.—A Lady enters from the Top of the Stage, and comes down in a hurry.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I proteſt I have been three quarters of an hour getting from the top of the ſtreet to the door!—I really believe, when people give routes, they think more of the buſtle they occaſion without doors, than the company they have within.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Oh yes! I am quite of that opinion.—The noiſe and racket in the ſtreets are frequently the pleaſanteſt part of the entertainment; and to plague one's ſober neighbours is delightful! Ha! ha! ha! My next-door friend, Mrs. Saffron, always wheels into the country on my public
nights,—on pretence of her delicate nerves; but the truth is, her rooms will hold but ſix card-tables, and mine thirteen.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Gent.
sp.p: Well, I proteſt I wiſh the ladies would baniſh cards from their aſſemblies, and give us ſomething in the ſtyle of the Converſaziones.

sp.speaker: 2d Gent.
sp.p: Oh no, Sir Charles, that won't do on this ſide the Alps;—we have no knack at converſation:—we think too much to be able to talk. Good talkers never think. Sir Harry Glare, full of bons mots, never thinks.—I myſelf am allowed to be tolerable, yet I never think.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh, that I believe all your friends will allow.—Hey-dey! here comes Lord Sparkle's borough acquaintance—Mr. Pendragon.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.p: Bobs, Miſs Belmour, how d'ye do? I didn't think to ſee you.—Mr. Fitzherbert brought me here, and I have been examining every face, to ſee if I knew any body; but fine ladies are ſo alike, that one muſt have long intimacy to know one's acquaintance!—Red cheeks, white necks, and ſmiling lips, croud every room.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hey-dey! a natural curioſity!—Pray, Sir, how long have you been in the world?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: How long! Juſt twenty years, laſt Lammas.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Poh, I don't enquire into your age! How long is it ſince you left your native woods?—Was you ever at a route before?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Aye, that I was, laſt week!—It beat this all to nothing.—'Twas at our neighbour's the Wine-Merchant's—at his country-houſe at Kentiſh-Town.

sp.speaker: 2d Lady.
sp.p: Oh, lud! I wiſh I had been of your party! I ſhould have enjoy'd a Kentiſh-Town route.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Oh, you muſt have been pleaſed; for the rooms were ſo little, and the company ſo large, that every thing was done with one conſent. We were pack'd ſo cloſe, that if one party moved, all the reſt were obliged to obey the motion.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Delightful!—Well, Sir—

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p:
We had all the fat widows, notable miſſes, and managing wives of the pariſh; ſo there was no ſcandal, for they were all there.—At length the aſſembly broke up.—Such clattering, and ſqueedging down the gangway ſtaircaſe,
whilſt the little foot-boy hawl'd from the paſſage, "Miſs Bobbin's bonnet is ready!"—"Mrs. Sugar-Plumb's lanthorn waits!"—"Mrs. Peppercorn's pattens ſtop the way!"

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh, you creature, come with me! I muſt exhibit him in the next room.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, ſtay!—Take my card.—I ſhall have company next Wedneſday, and I inſiſt on yours.—He is really amuſing!— (Enter Lord Sparkle from the top.) But hide your diminiſh'd heads, ye Beaus and Witlings! for here comes Lord Sparkle.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: I hope the Belles won't hide theirs; for in an age where the head is ſo large a part of the Lady, one ſhould look about for the ſex.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Gent.
sp.p: Well, my Lord, you ſee I have obey'd your ſummons! I ſhould not have been here, notwithſtanding Lady Bell's invitation, had you not preſs'd it.

sp.speaker: 2d Gent.
sp.p: Nor I! I promis'd to meet a certain Lady in the Gallery at the Opera to night,—and I regret that I did not; for I ſee her huſband is here.—Why did you preſs us ſo earneſtly to come?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Why, 'faith, to have as many witneſſes as I could to my glory!—This night is given by Lady Bell to ME.—I am the hero of the fête, and expect your gratulations. Here the dear creature comes!

div.stage: LADY BELL comes down from the top, addreſſing the Company.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: How do you do?—how do you do? (on each ſide) You wicked creature, why did you diſappoint me laſt night! Lady Harriet, I have not ſeen you this age! Oh, Lord Sparkle! I have been detain'd from my company by Mr. Fitzherbert, planning a ſcheme for your amuſement.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Indeed! I did not expect that attention from him; tho' I acknowledge my obligations to your Ladyſhip's politeneſs.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: That air of ſelf-poſſeſſion, I fancy, would be incommoded, if you gueſs'd at the entertainment.—Have you ſeen Mr. Beauchamp?

sp.speaker: Spark,
sp.p: For a moment.—But, charming Lady Bell, (taking her hand) I ſhall make you expire with laughing. I really believe the poor fellow explained your meſſage in his own favour, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Ridiculous! ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Ha! 'tis true! There they are, retired from the croud, and enjoying the privacy of lovers.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: See there he is! I long to have a little badinage on the ſubject.—Let us teaze him.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Oh, nothing can be more delightful!—"Hither, ſighing ſhepherd, come!"—Come, Beauchamp, take one laſt, one lingering look!—ſha'n't he, Lady Bell?

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Doubtleſs,—if he has your Lordſhip's leave.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: He ſeems aſtoniſh'd—ha, ha, ha!—Nay, it is cruel!—If the poor youth has the misfortune to be ſtricken, you know he can't reſiſt fate.—Ixion ſighed for Juno.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Yes, and he was puniſh'd too. What puniſhment, Mr. Beauchamp, ſhall we decree for you?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: I am aſtoniſh'd!—Was it for this your Ladyſhip commanded me to attend you?

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: How did I command you? Do you remember the words?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: I do, Madam.—You bid me come this evening, that I might behold you in the preſence of the man your heart prefers.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and now—now you ſee me!—

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Oh, the ſweet confuſion of the ſweet confeſſion!

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! this oſtentation of felicity, Madam, is ungenerous, ſince you know my heart; 'tis unworthy you! But I thank you for it—I have a pang the leſs.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, are you going?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: This inſtant, Madam.—I came in obedience to your commands; but my chaiſe is at your door, and before your gay aſſembly breaks up, I ſhall be far from London, and in a day or two from England. I probably now ſee your Ladyſhip for the laſt time.—Adieu!

sp.speaker: Lady Bell.
sp.p: Stay, Mr. Beauchamp!

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Ay, prithee ſtay! I believe Lady Bell has a mind to make you her conjugal father at the wedding.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p:
I forgive you, my Lord.—Exceſs of happineſs frequently overflows into inſolence, and it is the privilege of felicity to be unfeeling.—But how, Madam, has the humble paſſion which has ſo long conſumed my life, rendered me ſo hateful to you, as to prompt you to this barbarity? I have not inſulted you with my love; I have
ſcarcely dared whiſper it to myſelf: how then have I deſerved—

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: O mercy, don't be ſo grave! I am not inſenſible to your merit, nor have I beheld your paſſion with diſdain.—But what can I do? Lord Sparkle has ſo much faſhion, ſo much elegance—ſo much—

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: My deareſt Lady Bell, you juſtify my ideas of your diſcernment: and thus I thank you for the diſtinguiſhed honour

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: Oh you falſe-hearted man!

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Hey-dey!

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: Don't believe a word he ſays, for all you are ſo fine a Lady. He'll tell you of happineſs and miſery, and this, and that, and the other, but'tis all common-place and hyperbōlé—and all that ſort of thing.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Indeed! What has this young Lady claims on your Lordſhip?

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Claims! Ha! ha! ha! Surely your Ladyſhip can anſwer that in a ſingle glance. Claims! Ha! ha! ha! Is it my fault that a little ruſtic does not know the language of the day? Compliments are the ready coin of converſation, and 'tis every one's buſineſs to underſtand their value.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: True, my Lord, true;—and pray inſtruct me what was the value of the compliment, when you told me I ſhould make a figure in the Guards, and that you would ſpeak to your great friends to make me a colonel?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Value! Why, of juſt as much as it would bring! You thought it ſo valuable then, that you got me a hundred extra votes on the ſtrength of it; and you are now a little ungrateful wretch, to pretend 'twas worth nothing.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: But here, Lord Sparkle, is a Lady who claims a right on a different foundation. She had no Election intereſt to provoke your flatteries, yet you have not ſcrupled to profeſs love to her, whilſt under the roof of her friend, whoſe hand you was ſoliciting in marriage.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yes, I intreat your Ladyſhip not to fancy that you are to break the hearts of half our ſex by binding Lord Sparkle in the adamantine chains of marriage.—I boaſt an equal right with you, and don't flatter yourſelf I ſhall reſign him.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Mere malice, Lady Bell! Fitzherbert's malice!—I never had a ſerious thought of Miſs Manners in my life.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: What, my Lord! and have you dared talk of love to that Lady without a ſerious thought?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Hey-dey! what right have you—

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Oh, very trifling! only the right of a Huſband—The Lady ſo honour'd by your love-making in jeſt is my wife; in courſe, all obligations to her devolve on me.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Your wife! My dear Belville, I give you joy with all my ſoul! You ſee 'tis always dangerous to keep ſecrets from your friends. But is any body elſe coming? Have I any new crimes to be accus'd of? Any more witneſſes coming to the bar?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: No; but I am a witneſs in a new cauſe, and accuſe you of loading the mind of my friend Beauchamp with a ſenſe of obligation you had neither ſpirit or juſtice to confer.

sp.speaker: Lady Bell
sp.p: A Commiſſion, my Lord, which was ſent Mr. Beauchamp under a blank cover, by one who could not bear to ſee his noble ſpirit dependent on your caprices.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: And when his ſentiments pointed out your Lordſhip as his benefactor, you accepted the honour, and have laid heavy taxes on his gratitude.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Well, and what is there in all that? Beauchamp did not know to whom he was obliged; and wou'dn't it have been a moſt unchriſtian thing to let a good action run about the world belonging to nobody?—I found it a ſtray orphan, and ſo father'd it.—But you, Fitzherbert, I ſee are the lawful owner of the brat; ſo prithee take it back, and thank me for the honour of my patronage.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Your affected pleaſantry, Lord Sparkle, may ſhield you from reſentment, but it will not from contempt. Your effrontery—

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p:
Effrontery! Prithee make diſtinctions!—What in certain lines would be effrontery, in me is only the eaſe of Faſhion; that delightful thing, which enables me at this moment to ſtand ſerene amidſt your meditated ſtorm.—
Come, my dear Lady Bell, let us leave theſe good gentry, and love ourſelves amidſt the delights of faſhion, and the charms of bon ton.

sp.speaker: Lady Bell.
sp.p: Pardon me, my Lord! As caprice is abſolutely neceſſary to the character of a fine lady, you will not be ſurpris'd if I give an inſtance of it now; and, ſpite of your elegance, your faſhion, and your wit, preſent my hand to this poor ſoldier—who boaſts only worth, ſpirit, honour, and love.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Have a care, Madam!—Feelings like mine are not to be trifled with! Once already the hopes you have inſpir'd—

sp.speaker: Lady Bell.
sp.p: The hour of trifling is paſt; and ſurely it cannot appear extraordinary, that I prefer the internal worth of an uncorrupted heart, to the outward poliſh of a mind too feeble to ſupport itſelf againſt vice, in the ſeductive forms of faſhionable diſſipation.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Hey-dey! what, is your Ladyſhip in the plot?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: The plot has been deeper laid than you, my Lord, have been able to conceive. As I have the misfortune to be related to you, I thought it my duty to watch over your conduct. I have ſeen your plans, which generally tended to your confuſion and diſgrace; and many of them have been defeated, tho' you knew not by what means. But what fate does your Lordſhip deſign for theſe young people, decoy'd by you from their native ignorance and home?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Let them return to their native ignorance and home as faſt as they can.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: No, no; hang me if I do that!—I know Life now, and Life I'll have—Hyde-Park, Plays, Operas, and all that ſort of thing.—But, Old Gentleman, as you promis'd to do ſomething for me, what think ye of a Commiſſion?—The Captain there can't want his now; ſuppoſe you turn it over to me?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: No, young man, you ſhall be taken care of; but the requiſites of a ſoldier are not thoſe of pertneſs and aſſurance. Intrepid ſpirit, nice honour, generoſity, and underſtanding, all unite to form him.—It is theſe which will make a Britiſh ſoldier once again the firſt character in Europe.—It is ſuch ſoldiers who muſt make England once again invincible, and her glittering arms triumphant in every quarter of the globe.

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p:
Well, Bobby may do as he will—I'll go back to Cornwall directly, and warn all my neighbours to take ſpecial
care how they truſt to a Lord's promiſes at an Election again.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Well, great attempts and great failings mark the life of a man of ſpirit!—There is eclat even in my diſappointment to-night; and I am ready for a freſh ſet of adventures to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Incorrigible man!—But I have done with you.—Beauchamp has anſwered all my hopes, and the diſcernment of this charming woman, in rewarding him, merits the happineſs that awaits her; and that I may give the fulleſt ſanction to her choice, I declare him heir to my eſtate. This, I know, is a ſtroke your Lordſhip did not expect.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: And was it then to you, Sir!—The tumults of my gratitude—

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Your conduct has compleatly rewarded me; and in adopting you—

sp.speaker: Lady Bell.
sp.p: Oh, I proteſt againſt that!—Our union would then appear a prudent, ſober buſineſs, and I ſhould loſe the credit of having done a mad thing for the ſake of the man—my heart prefers.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: To you I reſign him with pleaſure: his fate is in your hands.

sp.speaker: Lady Bell.
sp.p: Then he ſhall continue a ſoldier—one of thoſe whom Love and his Country detain to guard her deareſt, laſt poſſeſſions.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Love and my Country! Yes, ye ſhall divide my heart!—Animated by ſuch paſſions, our forefathers were invincible; and if we wou'd preſerve the freedom and independence they obtain'd for us, we muſt imitate their virtues.
